name: UndoList

aliases.name: UndoList
aliases.comment:
The UndoList data structure.
An UndoList has:

1. A list of past states
2. A present state
3. A list of future states


The head of the past list is the most recent state and the head of the future
list is the next state. (i.e., the tails of both lists point away from the
present)
aliases.type: { past : List state, present : state, future : List state }

types.name: Action
types.comment:
Simple UndoList Action type. This is a simple type that can be used for
most use cases. This works best when paired with the `update` function as
`update` will perform the corresponding operations on the undolist automatically.

Consider using your own data type only if you really need it.

values.name: andMap
values.type: UndoList (a -> b) -> UndoList a -> UndoList b

values.name: andThen
values.type: UndoList a -> (a -> UndoList b) -> UndoList b

values.name: connect
values.comment:
Connect two undo-lists end to end. The present of the first undolist is
considered the present of the output undolist.
values.type: UndoList state -> UndoList state -> UndoList state

values.name: flatMap
values.type: (a -> UndoList b) -> UndoList a -> UndoList b

values.name: flatten
values.comment: Flatten an undo-list.

values.name: foldl
values.comment: Reduce an undo-list from the left (or from the past)
values.type: (a -> b -> b) -> b -> UndoList a -> b

values.name: foldp
values.comment:
Analog of Signal.foldp

This shorthand is defined simple as follows:

    foldp update initial =
      Signal.foldp (update update) (fresh initial)

This allows you to foldp on undo-lists without having to explicitly sprinkle
in undolist-specific code.
values.type: (action -> state -> state) -> state -> Signal (Action action) -> Signal (UndoList state)

values.name: foldr
values.comment: Reduce an undo-list from the right (or from the future)
values.type: (a -> b -> b) -> b -> UndoList a -> b

values.name: forget
values.comment:
Forget the past and look to the future!
This simply clears the past list.

i.e.
    forget (UndoList [3,2,1] 4 [5,6]) == UndoList [] 4 [5,6]

values.name: fresh
values.comment: Turn a state into an undo-list with neither past nor future.

values.name: fromList
values.comment:
Convert a list to undolist. The provided state is used as the present
state and the list is used as the future states.

    fromList 1 [2,3,4] == UndoList [] 1 [2,3,4]

values.name: hasFuture
values.comment: Check if the undo-list has any future states.

values.name: hasPast
values.comment: Check if the undo-list has any past states.

values.name: length
values.comment: Get the full length of an undo-list

values.name: lengthFuture
values.comment: Get the length of the future

values.name: lengthPast
values.comment: Get the length of the past.

values.name: mailbox
values.comment:
Shorthand for

    Signal.mailbox << New

Allows you to create a mailbox of undo-list actions given an action.

In many cases, you might be better off just doing:

    myMailbox = Signal.mailbox Reset

This allows you to avoid the problem of coming up with an initial value for
your mailbox.

values.name: map
values.comment:
Map a function over an undo-list.
Be careful with this. The function will be applied to the past and the future
as well. If you just want to change the present, use `mapPresent`.

A good use case for `map` is to encode an undo-list as JSON.

Example:

    import UndoList.Encode as Encode

    encode encoder undolist =
      map encoder undolist
      |> Encode.undolist

values.name: map2
values.type: (a -> b -> c) -> UndoList a -> UndoList b -> UndoList c

values.name: mapAction
values.comment: Map a function over an action.

values.name: mapPresent
values.comment: Apply a function only on the present.

values.name: new
values.comment:
Add a new present state to the undo-list, turning the old
present state into a past state and erasing the future.

values.name: redo
values.comment:
If the undo-list has any future states, set the next
future state as the current state and turn the old present state
into a past state.

i.e.

    redo (UndoList [3,2,1] 4 [5,6]) == UndoList [4,3,2,1] 5 [6]

values.name: reduce
values.comment: Alias for `foldl`
values.type: (a -> b -> b) -> b -> UndoList a -> b

values.name: reset
values.comment:
Reset the undo-list by returning to the very first state
and clearing all other states.

i.e.

    reset (UndoList [3,2,1] 4 [5,6]) == UndoList [] 1 []

values.name: reverse
values.comment: Reverse an undo-list.

values.name: toList
values.comment:
Convert an undo-list to a list :

    toList (UndoList [3,2,1] 4 [5,6]) == [1,2,3,4,5,6]

values.name: undo
values.comment:
If the undolist has any past states, set the most recent past
state as the current state and turn the old present state into
a future state.

i.e.

    undo (UndoList [3,2,1] 4 [5,6]) == UndoList [2,1] 3 [4,5,6]

values.name: update
values.comment:
Convert a function that updates the state to a function that updates an undo-list.
This is very useful to allow you to write update functions that only deal with
the individual states of your system and treat undo/redo as an add on.


Example:

    -- Your update function
    update action state =
      case action of
        ... -- some implementation

    -- Your new update function
    update' = UndoList.update update
values.type: (action -> state -> state) -> Action action -> UndoList state -> UndoList state

values.name: view
values.comment:
Function to help not having to deal with the full undolist from with
your actual view function.

Suppose you define the following:

    initial : model
    update : action -> model -> model
    view : Address (UndoList.Action action) -> model -> view
    address : Address (UndoList.Action action)
    signal : Signal (UndoList.Action action)

Then, you could construct the main function as follows:

    main =
      Signal.map (UndoList.view view address)
        (Signal.foldp (UndoList.update update) (UndoList.fresh initial) signal)
values.type: (Address (Action action) -> state -> view) -> Address (Action action) -> UndoList state -> view

name: UndoList.Decode
comment:
Decode UndoList submodule.

Provides JSON decoders for Timelines and UndoList Actions.

# Decoders
@docs undolist, action

values.name: action
values.comment: Decode an undo-list action given a decoder of actions.

values.name: undolist
values.comment: Decode an undo-list given a decoder of state.

name: UndoList.Encode
comment:
Encode UndoList submodule.

Provides JSON encoders for Timelines and UndoList Actions.

# Encoders
@docs undolist, action

values.name: action
values.comment:
Encode an UndoList Action of JSON values.
Best paired with the `mapAction` function from UndoList.

    encodeAction actionEncoder =
      UndoList.mapAction actionEncoder >> action

values.name: undolist
values.comment:
Encode an undolist of JSON values.
Best paired with the `map` function from UndoList.

    encodeUndoList stateEncoder  =
      UndoList.map stateEncoder >> undolist

name: UndoList.Random
comment:
Random UndoList Submodule.

Provides random undolist and undolist action generators.

# Generators
@docs undolist, action

values.name: action
values.comment:
Generate random undolist actions given an action generator.

Generates actions with the following probabilities:

- Reset  : 5%
- Forget : 5%
- Undo   : 30%
- Redo   : 30%
- New    : 30%

values.name: undolist
values.comment:
Random UndoList Generator constructor.
Given a generator of state, a length for the past, and a length for the future,
generate a random undolist of states.

    undolist pastLength futureLength generator
values.type: Int -> Int -> Generator state -> Generator (UndoList state)

name: UndoList.Shrink
comment:
Shrink UndoList Submodule.

Provides shrinking strategies for timelines and actions.

# Shrinkers
@docs undolist, action

values.name: action
values.comment:
Shrink an undo-list action given an action shrinker.
Considers `Reset` to be most minimal.

values.name: undolist
values.comment: Shrink an undo-list of states given a shrinker of states.
